column9: Conclusions. We propose a scheme of an experimental facility for determining the thermal conductivity of samples of composite materials in the form of plates, bars, and fiber bundles in the direction of their reinforcement and have substantiated the experimental conditions. In the course of the experiment, in a carbon-filled plastic sample a nonstationary temperature field, whose gradient coincided with the direction of the sample reinforcement plane, was created. We have investigated the possible errors in determining the thermal conductivity of a composite material and the influence of the thermal conductivity of its insulator on their level. Part of this work was supported by the Russian Foundation for Basic Research (grant No. 12-08-00305-a).

column9: LOURDES FARRUGIA received a BSc (Hons.) in Mathematics and Physics and a MSc in Physics from the University of Malta in 2008 and 2009, respectively. She joined the Physics department in 2011 as a Research Officer working in an Electromagnetics laboratory funded by the European Regional Development Fund (ERDF). She obtained a PhD from the University of Malta in 2016. Her research interests are mainly focused on aspects of instrumentation and measurement of physical quantities, especially sensor design, applied electromagnetics (in particular, dielectric properties of biological tissue), electromagnetic compatibility, and biological effects of electromagnetic radiation.

column9: is study was undertaken by the International Expedition of BirdsRussia funded from multiple sources. Many expedition members, especially Nikolay Yakushev and Vyacheslav Gabyshev, helped with fieldwork by finding nests and making observations of the birds with geolocators. Sergei Kharitonov supplied information about ring recoveries in the database of the Moscow Bird Ringing Center. Eldar Rakhimberdiev, Vladimir Arkhipov and Oleg Belyalov helped with access to literature sources. Maksim Dementyev was instrumental in finding the best map for displaying plover fl ight tracks. Involvement of PST in data analysis and writing of the paper was supported by the Russian Science Foundation project no. 14-50-00029. EYL used ‘Beam-M’ facility equipment for statistical calculations. Special thanks are extended to Terje Lislevand and Raymond Klaassen whose extensive review has been invaluable and resulted in a greatly improved manuscript. e paper was further improved a lot by the editors, José Alves, Jacquie Clark and Humphrey Sitters.

It was tried out in the Summer School conducted by the Center for Pre-University Training of Bauman Moscow State Technical University in 2016 at the International Children's Center “Artek”. The module “Measurement Errors”, in which the above idea is realized, is one of the main sections of this program. The work on this program is also carried out within the framework of the Center for Technological Support of Education and in the physical laboratory of the department “Fundamentals of Physics” of Bauman Moscow State Technical University.

column3: Measurement of Blowout Resistance of Fibrous Sound-Proof Materials
column6: Bauman Moscow State Technical University, Moscow, Russian Federation

column8: 14-08-00703, RFBR, Russian Foundation for Basic Research
column9: Conclusion. The blowout resistance of fibrous SAM is measured by a direct method. The derived dependence of blowout resistance on material density is approximated with high precision analytically by a power function. The use of dimensionless numbers for processing experimental data and the structural coefficient made it possible to establish the value of the exponent of the power function as equal to two. The direct proportionality of the structural coefficient and the inverse proportionality of blowout resistance to the diameter of fiber were also established. This study was supported by the Russian Foundation for Basic Research (Project No. 14-08-00703).

column9: Gennady V. Savrasov is a Professor of the Department of Biomedical and Technical Systems at the Bauman Moscow State Technical University. He holds a PhD degree in Biomechanics. His research interests include ultrasonic technologies in surgery, medical robotics, biomechanics, biomaterials, and remote surgeries. He is the current Chairman of Ultrasonic Angiosurgery of the Russian Society of Angiologists and Vascular Surgeons and a member of the European Society of Biochemical Engineering Sciences. He is an author and co-author of more than 80 manuscripts in the field of medical equipment.
